meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny!

Alright, folks, gather 'round! I'm about to dish out my thoughts on Astor: Blade of the Monolith, and trust me, it's gonna be a wild ride. Now, I know what you're thinking - "Another review, another score, another bland summary." But fear not, dear readers, for I'm here to shake things up with some much-needed humor and wit.

First off, let's get this out of the way: Astor: Blade of the Monolith is an action RPG that's got its roots firmly planted in old-school territory. SpazioGames says it's "decent" - I think they mean "good, but not great." And honestly, that's a fair assessment.

Now, where do our critics agree? Well, God is a Geek and The Games Machine both seem to enjoy the game once you've got a good selection of weapons and attacks unlocked. And let me tell you, when you're slicing through hordes of baddies with ease, it's hard not to have fun.

Shacknews takes a slightly different approach, praising Astor for taking familiar concepts and adding new context. They even give it props for understanding character action-style combat (I mean, who doesn't love a good dash-of-attack combo?). And honestly, I think that's what sets Astor apart - its willingness to take risks and try something new.

But not everyone is having a groovy time in Astoria. RPGamer gives the game a solid thumbs-down, citing underdeveloped gameplay, bugs galore, and a plot that could've used some serious punching up (I mean, come on, who doesn't love a good plot? It's like the unsung hero of gaming!). And GameSkinny agrees - they think Astor's got plenty of bright ideas, but just can't execute them well enough.

So what's the verdict? Well, I'm not gonna give you a score (wink, wink). But let me tell you, as someone who's had their fair share of gaming mishaps and triumphs, Astor: Blade of the Monolith is an adventure worth taking. Just don't expect perfection - but hey, when did that ever stop anyone from having fun?

Stay groovy, gamers!
